title: The Bachelor's Abbie Chatfield snubs Chelsie McLeod and Matt Agnew in tribute piece
text:
She's endured a difficult six months, after being rejected by Matt Agnew on the season finale of The Bachelor.

And on Friday, Abbie Chatfield took to Instagram to share a lengthy post thanking the 'amazing angels' who helped her get through the tough period.

But while she was quick to thank third-place finalist Helena Sauzier, she notably missed out former pal Chelsie McLeod - who won The Bachelor's heart - and Matt himself.

'Amazing angels': Taking to Instagram Friday, Abbie Chatfield (centre) wrote an emotional tribute to some of her pals, including third-place finalist Helena Sauzier but she didn't mention Chelsie McLeod and Matt Agnew

'Just some of the amazing angels who have helped me through the last six months. Love you lots,' the 24-year-old wrote, alongside pictures with some of her close ones.

Her post comes after Abbie defended herself in a passionate essay online, saying she was unfairly portrayed as the show's 'villain' during her stint earlier this year.

In an article for Whimn, she said her fellow contestants misinterpreted her loud, playful and sexually forward personality.

So loved-up: Matt Agnew (right) is still happily with his show winner Chelsie McLeod (left) following their journey on The Bachelor

'I never did anything mean': The Bachelor's Abbie Chatfield has revealed she was blindsided by her 'villain edit'

'I never did anything mean to any of the women, beyond spilling the beans on the "dog c***t" saga,' she wrote.

'I never spoke of any other woman to Matt [Agnew], I never said anything insulting to any of the women and I certainly didn't make any of them feel the way that I felt. Yet somehow, I was the villain.'

Abbie said some of the women made her feel unwelcome in the mansion, and she found herself feeling paranoid and crying almost every day.

Emotional journey: The 24-year-old property analyst defended herself in a passionate essay, saying she was unfairly portrayed as the show's antagonist

She added that having her heart broken in the finale was made worse by the bullying she faced on social media.

Abbie endured months of harassment on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram from strangers who shamed her for how she behaved on screen.

'It is extremely disheartening and concerning to see the eager willingness of the Australian public to jump on this bandwagon,' she wrote.

Her say: 'I never did anything mean to any of the women,' Abbie wrote in an article for Whimn

In a final message to reality TV fans, Abbie concluded: 'Analyse your opinions, consider if your message or comment will add or take [away] from the recipient's day and finally, please, just be kind.'

It's not the first time Abbie has taken aim at her online trolls.

In a recent Instagram post, she complained about being 'sl*t shamed' for the clothes she wore on The Bachelor as well as her steamy dates with Matt Agnew.

She wrote: 'This is something I did not expect in 2019. Sex is essential to a successful relationship for me, as is sexual chemistry and the ability to express that comfortably with my partner.'
description: She's endured a difficult six months, after being rejected by Matt Agnew on the heartbreaking season finale of The Bachelor.
authors: Alisha Buaya For Daily Mail Australia
